==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|en|frem|frim|fren|fraim|fremed|framed}} * {{alter|en|frammit|fremmit|frempt||Scottish}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|en|enm|fremde||strange, foreign}}, {{m|enm|fremede}}, from {{inh|en|ang|fremde}}, {{m|ang|fremede}}, {{m|ang|fremeþe||foreign, strange}}, from {{inh|en|gem-pro|*framaþiz||foreign, not one's own}}, from {{inh|en|ine-pro|*perəm-}}, {{m|ine-pro|*prom-||forth, forward}}, from {{m|ine-pro|*por-||forward, through}}. Cognate with {{cog|sco|fremmit}}, {{m|sco|frempt||fremd}}, {{cog|fy|frjemd||strange, fremd}}, {{cog|nl|vreemd||strange, foreign}}, {{cog|de|fremd||fremd, strange, foreign}}, {{cog|sv|främmande||foreign, outlandish, strange}}. More at {{l|en|from}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|RP|GenAm}} {{enPR|frĕmd}}, {{IPA|en|/fɹɛmd/}} ===Adjective=== {{en-adj|er|more}} # {{lb|en|rare|chiefly|dialectal}} [[strange|Strange]]; [[foreign]]; [[alien]]; [[outlandish]]; far off or away; [[distant]]. #* '''1873''', Blackwood's Edinburgh magazine: #*: [...] and if I'm to be no more hereafter to them that belong to me, than to legions of strange angels, or a whole nation of '''fremd''' folk ! # {{lb|en|rare|chiefly|dialectal}} Not [[akin]]; [[unrelated]]. #* '''1875''', John Howard Nodal, George Milner, ''A glossary of the Lancashire dialect'': #*: Thus, a person living with a family to whom he is not related is termed "a '''fremd''' body." If it were asked, "Is he akin to you?" the answer would be, "Nawe, he's '''fremd'''," i.e. "he's one of us, but not a relation." #* '''1851''', Mrs. Oliphant (Margaret), ''Passages in the life of Mrs. Margaret Maitland of Sunnyside'': #*: [...] seeing that they were '''fremd''' in heart, if they were kin in blood. # {{lb|en|rare|chiefly|dialectal}} [[out of the ordinary|Out of the ordinary]]; [[unusual]]; [[strange]], [[weird]]. #: {{ux|en|a '''fremd''' day}} #: {{ux|en|Something '''fremd''' has been going on here.}} #: {{ux|en|A '''fremd''' man this.}} # {{lb|en|obsolete}} [[wild|Wild]]; [[untamed]]. ====Derived terms==== * {{l|en|fremdling}} * {{l|en|fremedly}} * {{l|en|fremsome}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|rare|or|chiefly dialectal}} [[stranger]]; [[guest]] # {{lb|en|archaic|or|obsolete}} an [[enmity]] ===References=== * 1906, The Century Dictionary and Cyclopedia, "fremd". * 1883, The Imperial Dictionary of the English Language, "fremde, fremed". [[Category:en:People]] ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|vremde}}, {{m|goh|vremede}}, from {{inh|de|goh|fremidi}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*framaþiz}}. Cognate with {{cog|en|fremd}}, {{cog|nl|vreemd}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/fʁɛmt/}} * {{audio|de|De-fremd.ogg|Audio}} ===Adjective=== {{de-adj|er|fremdesten}} # [[strange]] # [[foreign]] #* '''2010''', ''{{w|Der Spiegel}}'', issue [http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/index-2010-28.html 28/2010], page 93: #*: Fast alle Amerikaner können ihre Wurzeln in '''fremde''' Länder zurückverfolgen, und deshalb ist Einwanderung ein Thema, das die Identität der USA auf besondere Weise berührt. #*:: Nearly all Americans can trace back their roots into foreign countries, and therefore immigration is an issue that touches the identity of the US in a special way. # [[external]] ====Declension==== {{de-decl-adj|fremd|fremder|fremdest}} ====Derived terms==== {{der4 |de|befremden |entfremden |fremdartig |Fremder |Fremdkapital |Fremdling |Fremdscham |fremdschämen |Fremdsprache |verfremden }} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} ---- ==Middle English== ===Adjective=== {{head|enm|adjective}} # {{alternative form of|enm|fremde}} ---- ==Scots== ===Adjective=== {{head|sco|adjective}} # {{alternative form of|sco|fremmit}}
